title: 108_s215
content: The "Guaranteeing a United and Resolute Defense Act of 2003" or the "GUARD Act of 2003" provides funding assistance for homeland security activities of the National Guard. The "GUARD Act of 2003" allows the Secretary of Defense to provide funding assistance to States for homeland security activities of the National Guard. States must have a homeland security activities plan in effect to be eligible for assistance. The funds can be used for personnel expenses and equipment operation and maintenance. The "GUARD Act of 2003" allows the Secretary of Defense to provide funding assistance to States for homeland security activities of the National Guard, including operation, maintenance, procurement, and training. States must have a homeland security activities plan detailing the use of National Guard personnel and equipment for eligible activities. The "GUARD Act of 2003" allows the Secretary of Defense to provide funding assistance to States for homeland security activities of the National Guard. States must have a plan certifying the use of National Guard personnel and equipment for eligible activities, including certifications from the Governor and Attorney General of the State. The "GUARD Act of 2003" requires States to have a homeland security activities plan approved by the Secretary of Defense. The plan must certify the use of National Guard personnel and equipment for activities serving a State law enforcement purpose, including transportation of aliens who violated terrorist laws. The Secretary of Defense must submit an annual report to Congress detailing the assistance provided under this section, including homeland security activities conducted, funds allocated to each State, and the impact on military training and readiness. Nothing in this section limits the authority of any National Guard unit. The National Guard of a State, when not in Federal service, has the authority to perform law enforcement functions as authorized by state laws. Definitions include the Governor as the commanding general of the National Guard in the District of Columbia, homeland security activities as defense against attacks, and the inclusion of the District of Columbia as a State. The term 'State' includes the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, and the Virgin Islands. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in chapter 1 of the title.
